metadata.title: Environment-friendly epoxidation of limonene using tungsten-based polyoxometalate catalyst

Fig. 1 Reaction pathway for epoxidation of limonene with H2O2. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 A visual representation of the sequential steps involved in the epoxidation process. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Limonene conversion (X) and yield to limonene-1,2-epoxide (LO), limonene bis-epoxide (Bis), limonene-1,2-diol (Diol) and selectivity to the desired epoxide products LO and Bis at three different limonene:H2O2: solvent mole ratios of 1:1:3, 1:1.5:3 and 1:2:3 using CHCl3 and EtOAc as solvents. 1:1:3 (a), 1:1.5:3 (b) and 1:2:3 (c) at 66 °C, refluxing CHCl3 (300 mol% with respect to limonene). 1:1:3 (c), 1:1.5:3 (d) and 1:2:3 (e) at 77 °C refluxing EtOAc (300 mol% respect to limonene); total volume 12.5 mL; 1000 rpm. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Effect of changes in inorganic salts. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Decrease in the concentration of limonene at different temperatures (30,40,50 °C) as a function of time. Reaction conditions: limonene (122 mmol, 19.8 mL), H2O2 30 wt% (122 mmol, 12.4 mL) in the presence of Na2WO4·2H2O (0.6 mmol, 0.2 g), H3PO4 42.5 wt% (0.15 mmol, 20.5 µl), Na2SO4 (36.6 mmol, 5.2 g), H2SO4 48.5 wt% (4.9 mmol, 532 µl), Adogen® 464 (1 g). Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Conversion of limonene and limonene-1,2-epoxide (LO) generated as a function of time. Reaction Conditions: limonene (122 mmol, 19.8 mL), H2O2 30 wt% (122 mmol, 12.4 mL) at different temperatures (30, 40, 50 °C) in the presence of Na2WO4·2H2O (0.6 mmol, 0.2 g), H3PO4 42.5 wt% (0.15 mmol, 20.5 µl), Na2SO4 (36.6 mmol, 5.2 g), H2SO4 48.5 wt% (4.9 mmol, 532 µl), Adogen® 464 (1 g). Fig. 6 Fig. 7 GC analysis of limonene epoxidation sample after 45 min. Conditions:50 °C and 1000 rpm. (I) limonene; (II) limonene-1,2-epoxide; (III) internal standard naphthalene; (IV). limonene-1,2-diol. Conversion of limonene:65%, selectivity to limonene-1,2-epoxide:92%, selectivity to limonene diol:8%. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Conversion of limonene and selectivity to limonene-1,2-epoxide (LO) over time. Conditions: limonene (122 mmol), H2O2 30 wt% (122 mmol), initial temperature 50 °C, Na2WO4·2H2O (1.2 mmol), H3PO4 42.5 wt% (0.15 mmol), Na2SO4 (36.6 mmol), H2SO4 48.5 wt% (4.9 mmol), Adogen® 464 (1 g). Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Mechanism of limonene epoxidation in the presence of H2O2 and QCl-ammonium salts. Total volume 12.5 mL. Exp. 1 to 4 at 66 °C under reflux with CHCl3and Exp. 5–8 at 77 °C under reflux with EtOAc; agitation speed: 1000 rpm; reaction time: 15 min. Table 1 Exp. Eze Supervision Formal analysis Writing – review & editing a Adam P. Harvey Methodology Supervision Project administration a a School of Engineering, Newcastle University, Newcastle upon Tyne, NE1 7RU, United Kingdom School of Engineering Newcastle University Newcastle upon Tyne NE1 7RU United Kingdom aSchool of Engineering, Newcastle University, Newcastle upon Tyne, NE1 7RU, United Kingdom b Department of Chemical and Polymer Engineering, University of Engineering and Technology Lahore, Faisalabad Campus, Pakistan Department of Chemical and Polymer Engineering University of Engineering and Technology Lahore Faisalabad Campus Pakistan bDepartment of Chemical and Polymer Engineering, University of Engineering and Technology Lahore, Faisalabad Campus, Pakistan c Department of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Universiti Putra Malaysia, 43400 UPM Serdang, Selangor, Malaysia Department of Chemical and Environmental Engineering Faculty of Engineering Universiti Putra Malaysia 43400 UPM Serdang Selangor Malaysia cDepartment of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Universiti Putra Malaysia, 43400 UPM Serdang, Selangor, Malaysia ⁎ Corresponding author. Terpene epoxides play a vital role as chemical intermediates in industries such as flavourings, fragrances, paints, and polymers manufacturing. However, current methods for limonene epoxidation suffer from low selectivity and environmental concerns. To address these limitations, we aimed to develop a highly selective and environmentally benign process for limonene epoxidation. Our approach involved employing hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) as an oxidant in the presence of tungsten-based polyoxometalates as catalysts. A novel catalyst was synthesized using sodium tungstate dihydrate (Na2WO4·2H2O), phosphoric acid (H3PO4), sulfuric acid (H2SO4), and sodium sulfate (Na2SO4) as an inorganic salt. We investigated the influence of various process variables, including the limonene:H2O2 molar ratio, reaction time, temperature, and solvent type, to optimize the epoxidation process. Through systematic screening, we achieved remarkable results, attaining 96% limonene conversion, 80% selectivity to limonene-1,2-epoxide, and 19% selectivity to limonene bis-epoxide within a short reaction time of 15 min. Notably, this high performance was accomplished by introducing H2O2 in a single step. To mitigate the hydrolysis of the epoxide, we employed sodium sulphate (Na2SO4) to saturate the reaction mixture. Furthermore, we proposed a comprehensive mechanism for the limonene epoxidation process using tungsten-based polyoxometalates as catalysts. Our kinetic study revealed a first-order reaction with respect to both limonene and the catalyst. Importantly, the decomposition of H2O2 was negligible under the investigated operating conditions, confirming the stability and efficiency of our approach. Our findings present eco-friendly, scalable, and catalytic epoxidation methods as valuable synthetic tools for converting inexpensive bio-renewable terpene feedstocks into essential chemical building blocks. The implications of our work extend to the synthesis of useful chemical products in a biorefinery setting, promoting a more sustainable and efficient utilization of terpenes. Graphical abstract Highly Selective and Environmentally Benign Epoxidation of Limonene Using Tungsten-Based Polyoxometalates Catalysts and Hydrogen Peroxide Image, graphical abstract Keywords Limonene Limonene-1,2-epoxide Epoxidation Hydrogen peroxide Polyoxometalates Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The epoxidation of terpenes is an important industrial process that produces valuable chemical intermediates for the manufacture of products such as flavours, fragrances, paints, and polymers. Conventional industrial methods employ peracids, which are not environmentally friendly and pose safety risks. Hence, there is a greater focus on using safer oxidants and energy-efficient processes that generate less waste [1]. H2O2 is a promising choice as an oxidant for liquid-phase reactions because it is affordable, easy to handle, and produces only water as the by-product [2,]. The main disadvantage of H2O2 is its instability, which leads to the decomposition in oxygen and water [3]. Tungsten-based catalysts are preferred for epoxidation because they avoid unproductive H2O2 decomposition [4–7]. Venturello's procedure using aqueous H2O2 as an oxidant and a combination of Na2WO4-H3PO4-quaternary ammonium salt as a catalyst is a good method for internal and terminal alkene epoxidation [8,9]. The main disadvantage of this process is that an excess of olefins is required [10]. Several variations of this process have been introduced, such as Noyori's method, which enhances the sodium tungsten-catalysed epoxidation of alkenes [11], and Ishii's method, which uses tungsten-based heteropolyacids and cetylpyridinium chloride [12]. However, there are still some issues related to oxirane ring opening, and the process can be complex. Takumi's method improves epoxide selectivity by using inorganic salts in the system [13]. However, this method is time-consuming and requires an excess of H2O2 and methyltrioctylammonium hydrogen sulfate as a phase-transfer catalyst, which is costly and difficult to obtain on a large scale. Polyoxometalates (POMs) are versatile compounds that have been used in catalysis due to their wide variety of structures, which can incorporate many elements from the periodic table [14,15]. POMs are composed of transition metals in the highest oxidation state from oxo-anionic clusters through the dissolution of metal ions in an aqueous solution [16]. The acidity of the proton centre is related to the metal ion charge, and the structure and stability of the complex depend largely on the pH of the solution. POMs with transition metal substitutions have gained a lot of interest due to their oxidatively stable catalysts. Apart from being used as a catalyst in epoxidation, POMs were also used as support to anchor single metal atoms [17,18]. This study focuses on limonene, one of the most used terpenes, for epoxidation. Limonene is a significant component in approximately 300 plant species [19,20], and the global production was approximately 70,000 tons in 2013 [21,22]. Limonene-1,2-epoxide is a desirable renewable monomer that can be utilized as a reagent as well as a recyclable solvent. Limonene-1,2-epoxide has already yielded commercially accessible polymeric resins [23]. Copolymerization with carbon dioxide produces biodegradable polycarbonates, and the cycloaddition of carbon dioxide produces cyclic carbonates, which are used as polar aprotic solvents and in the synthesis of polyurethanes [24–29]. Epoxidation of limonene is a complex process due to the presence of secondary reactions in addition to the main reaction, which produces limonene-1,2-diol [30], as shown in Fig. 1 . Epoxidation produces two isomers for the internal and external double bonds and four isomers for the bis-epoxide formed [19,31]. This work aims to provide a method for producing highly efficient epoxy compounds from limonene using inexpensive catalysts and reagents, free of safety concerns, and selective to epoxides in very short reaction times. A detailed study of the effects of various process parameters, such as the limonene/ H2O2 mole ratio, reaction time, temperature, and type of inorganic salt, was conducted. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials (R)-limonene (98%), hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) (30% w/w in H2O), chloroform (CHCl3), ethyl acetate (EtOAc), sodium tungstate dihydrate (Na2WO4·2H2O) (≥99%), phosphoric acid (H3PO4) (42.5%), Adogen® 464 phase-transfer catalyst, sulfuric acid (H2SO4) (48.5%), and anhydrous sodium sulfate (Na2SO4) (≥99.0%). All chemicals were purchased from Sigma Aldrich and used as received. 2.2 Experimental procedure Reactions were conducted using the Radleys Carousel 6 Plus Reaction Station™ equipped with a water-cooled aluminium reflux head, thermometer, and stirred hotplate, utilizing 50 mL vessels. In a typical experiment, an aqueous phase containing Na2WO4·2H2O, a 42.5 wt% H3PO4 solution, and H2O2 (30% solution in H2O) was stirred in a beaker for 15 min. Then, a 48.5 wt% H2SO4 solution and Na2SO4 were added and stirred for 15 min until dissolved. In the organic phase, limonene, Adogen® 464, and a solvent were mixed in vessels and heated to the desired temperature before adding the aqueous solution. The epoxidation reaction was carried out with intensive stirring at 1000 rpm at different temperatures, based on the solvent used in each experiment. Two solvents, chloroform (CHCl3) and ethyl acetate (EtOAc), were used with boiling points below 90 °C to prevent H2O2 breakdown. The reactions were performed at a temperature equal to the boiling point of the solvent. The mole ratio of limonene to H2O2, type of solvent, and temperature varied in the studies. Samples were collected at various time points after the reagents were mixed. GC-FID was used to analyse the organic layer that had been isolated from the aqueous solution. Fig. 2 provides the key components and actions involved in the methodology. 2.3 Sample analysis The reaction was also monitored at regular intervals by taking samples and analysed by gas chromatography (GC) and a flame ionization detector (FID), using a Hewlett Packard HP6890 Series, equipped with a column Elite 5MS (30 m, 0.25 mm ID, 0.25 µm Film Thickness). The products were quantified using the calibration curves obtained using standard solutions with naphthalene as the internal standard. The thermostat temperature was programmed as follows: isothermally at 80 °C for 4 min, an increase to 230 °C at a rate of 15 °C/min, and isothermally for 2 min. The total analysis time was 16 min. The retention times were the following:3.34 min for limonene, 6.30 min and 6.47 min for limonene-1,2-epoxide cis and trans isomers respectively, 9.67 min for naphthalene as an internal standard, 10.39 min for limonene bis-epoxide (Bis) and 13.54 min for limonene-1,2-diol. 2.4 In-situ Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy A Mettler Toledo React IR-4000 FTIR spectrometer (USA) equipped with a mercury cadmium telluride (MCT) band detector was used to monitor the in situ FTIR spectroscopy. The detector was cooled using liquid nitrogen in a specialized Dewar flask. The FTIR spectrometer was equipped with a K6 conduit with a 6.35 mm DiComp (diamond) probe measuring from 4000 to 650 cm–1. The instrument was linked to a PC interface, and iC-iR software was used to record the spectra and data. By minimizing the variation between scans, a signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) was first established to assure IR the correctness and consistency of the IR spectra. To remove the instrument's response to these elements, the device was further calibrated by obtaining the spectra of water vapour and ambient air. In absorbence mode, 40 co-added and averaged scans were performed for 15 s each to gather spectra with an 8 cm–1 spectral resolution. A two-point baseline that eliminated differences brought on by changes in the baseline during a scan was used to quantify the area under the peak. Peaks for limonene and limonene-1,2-epoxide were observed at 1150 cm–1 and 841 cm–1, respectively. 3 Results and discussion Limonene epoxidation was performed in an organic-aqueous biphasic system with a phase-transfer catalyst. A highly efficient, safe, and straightforward epoxidation process was used that required no expensive reagents and mild conditions. Excellent limonene conversion and 100% selectivity for the epoxide products, limonene-1,2-epoxide and limonene bis-epoxide, were achieved in less than 15 min. 3.1 Effect of limonene/H2O2 mole ratio Different molar ratios of limonene and H2O2 (30 wt% solution) were studied: 1:1, 1:1.5, 1:2, and 1:3 in CHCl3 and EtOAc solvents. A 1:3 (limonene: solvent) molar ratio was chosen to maintain isothermal conditions. To monitor the process kinetics, samples were taken at 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 10, and 15-min intervals. The use of solvents in biphasic systems helps to avoid unwanted side reactions. An organic solvent was necessary to obtain the desired results, and CHCl3 was chosen because it has been shown to perform well for alkene epoxidation [32]. EtOAc was also used as a solvent. The experimental matrix, which lists the number of reagents used in each experiment, is presented in Table 1 . All experiments were performed under reflux conditions using a high stirring speed of 1000 rpm to avoid the influence of the mass transfer coefficient. The total volume of the biphasic system was 12.5 mL. The reactions were performed at the boiling point of each solvent, which was 66 °C for CHCl3 (Exp. 1–4), and 77 °C for EtOAc (Exp. 5–8). The use of CHCl3 as a solvent resulted in better performance than EtOAc. Although limonene was completely converted in the absence of a solvent, it yielded no epoxide due to the formation of a more viscous organic phase that was difficult to separate from the aqueous phase. Therefore, an organic solvent was necessary to obtain the desired results. Fig. 3 illustrates the progress of limonene conversion over time and the selectivity of LO and Bis using CHCl3 and EtOAc at different limonene: H2O2 mole ratios. Excellent selectivity to epoxides and high conversion was achieved using equal amounts of H2O2 and limonene (limonene: H2O2 = 1:1 molar ratio). CHCl3 and EtOAc resulted in 65% and 72% limonene conversion, respectively, in only 15 min (Fig. 3a and d), with 100% selectivity to epoxides (90% LO and 9% Bis). Both CHCl3 and EtOAc showed comparable conversion and selectivity. These findings indicate that the solvent's polarity does not affect limonene conversion, in contrast to previous studies that demonstrated a decrease in conversion as solvent polarity increased [33]. In all trials, less than 1% of limonene was transformed into limonene-1,2-diol, making the epoxidation process completely selective for the desired products. The higher limonene conversion obtained using EtOAc as the solvent is most likely due to the higher temperature used (77 °C), which considerably accelerates the reaction rate. EtOAc is a superior solvent since it has a high limonene conversion rate and complete selectivity for the epoxides LO and Bis, eliminating the need for hazardous chlorinated hydrocarbons. An increase in the amount of H2O2 showed not only an increase in the limonene conversion but also an increase in the selectivity to Bis. With limonene: H2O2 molar ratio of 1:1.5, 96% limonene conversion and 80% selectivity to LO were achieved, while 19% selectivity was obtained for Bis. Increasing the amount of H2O2 to twice the limonene amount (limonene: H2O2 molar ratio = 1:2) resulted in a similar limonene conversion (98%) but with a slightly higher selectivity to Bis (26%) (Fig. 3b). The increase in the volume of the aqueous phase was accomplished by increasing the limonene: H2O2 molar ratio. This led to more interaction between H2O2, Na2SO4, and H3PO4, resulting in an active combination. When the concentration of the active complex was higher, it diffused more quickly into the organic phase, resulting in higher limonene conversion. Epoxidation of limonene with EtOAc also produced similar results, with increased limonene conversion and selectivity to bis. A higher limonene conversion and initial reaction rate were observed when the amount of H2O2 was increased from a 1:1 limonene: H2O2 mole ratio to 1:1.5, but there was no significant increase in Bis production (Fig. 3e). The use of twice the amount of H2O2 (i.e., 1:2 limonene: H2O2 molar ratio) resulted in virtually the same conversion and selectivity as using 1:1.5 limonene: H2O2. Therefore, doubling the amount of H2O2 is impractical because the benefits are negligible. To maintain a saturated aqueous phase, a large volume of the aqueous phase containing a considerable amount of Na2SO4 was used to increase the amount of oxidant, resulting in a triple mole ratio of H2O2 to limonene. However, this also increased the density of the aqueous phase, resulting in poor mixing and mass transfer issues and reduced conversions. These findings suggest that the optimal working conditions for the epoxidation of limonene are limonene: H2O2 ratio of 1.5. This ratio results in nearly complete limonene conversion, excellent selectivity for epoxide products, and a significant reduction in reaction time, requiring only 15 min compared to the more than 12 hrs found in most literature [34,35]. 3.2 Effect of change in inorganic salt The hydrolysis of the epoxide ring by H2O in the H2O2 solution reduces the selectivity of limonene oxide. To prevent this, adding an inorganic salt is one of the strategies proposed to increase the selectivity of terpene oxides [34,36]. Experiment 1 in Table 1 was performed to study the effect of the type of salt added to prevent epoxide hydrolysis, using magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) instead of sodium sulfate (Na2SO4). These salts may stabilize the reactive intermediates involved in the epoxidation process, favouring the desired product formation. As expected, using MgSO4 resulted in a considerable increase in the yield of generated limonene-1,2-diol (diol) (Fig. 4 ), whereas using Na2SO4 significantly reduced bis yield. The use of Na2SO4 effectively decreased LO hydrolysis. The exact mechanism of the salt effect is unclear, but it is suggested that the salt is ionized into the appropriate ions, resulting in a "salting-out" process [37]. As the ionic strength of the aqueous phase increased in the presence of Na2SO4 [36], ions repel non-electrolytes, such as limonene oxide, in the aqueous phase. This reduces the solubility of epoxides in the interphase, which inhibits hydrolysis [5]. 3.3 Kinetic studies To maintain isothermal conditions and quantify the kinetic parameters of the exothermic reaction, diluted solutions were utilized. Various proportions (mol%) of limonene, H2O2, Na2WO4·2H2O, H3PO4, H2SO4, Adogen® 464, and Na2SO4 were tested. The best results were obtained when limonene and H2O2 were used in equal equivalents, the amount of tungsten compound used was 0.5 mol% relative to the substrate, and the amount of phosphorous compound used was 25 mol% relative to the tungsten amount used. A saturated quantity of Na2SO4 was used to prevent hydrolysis without deactivating the catalytic H2O2 epoxidation system [34]. The amount of Na2SO4 added was estimated based on its solubility in H2O at 30 °C. The reaction used 122 mmol (19.8 mL) of limonene, 122 mmol (12.4 mL) of H2O2, 0.6 mmol (0.2 g) of Na2WO4·2H2O, 0.15 mmol (20.5 L) of 42.5 wt.% H3PO4, 2.4 (532 L) of 48.5 wt.% H2SO4, and 36.6 mmol (5.2 g) of Na2SO4. The experiments were conducted for 2 hrs at temperatures ranging from 30 to 50 °C with in-situ FTIR monitoring of limonene consumption and epoxide accumulation. Samples were collected at various intervals and analysed using GC-FID to detect all isomeric epoxides. Fig. 5 shows the changes in limonene concentrations over time, with an increasing limonene conversion rate observed at higher temperatures. Fig. 6 illustrates the high conversion obtained with 65% limonene conversion in just 45 min at 50 °C, a significant improvement over Sato's study [35], which took 12 hrs to achieve similar conversion levels. The chromatogram displayed in Fig. 7 indicates that only two products are formed during limonene transformation, namely limonene-1,2-epoxide (product II in Fig. 1) and limonene-1,2-diol (product III in Fig. 1), with a remarkable selectivity of 92% for limonene-1,2-epoxide. The rate constant increased with increasing temperature and catalyst loading, resulting in higher conversion and selectivity of 84% and 100%, respectively, in just 15 min. However, extending the reaction time beyond 45 min did not increase conversion but instead caused side reactions, resulting in decreased conversion and selectivity. The instability of the epoxide at high temperatures and acidic conditions caused it to hydrolyse. Therefore, to maintain 100% selectivity to LO and avoid complications, the reaction should be terminated after 45 min. Fig. 8 illustrates that increased reaction time does not necessarily lead to higher conversion. 3.3 Mechanism of the limonene epoxidation Fig. 9 illustrates the limonene epoxidation mechanism in the presence of H2O2 and the QCl-ammonium salt. The reaction mixture contained the oxidant H2O2 (30 wt% in water) and a water-soluble binary catalyst system Na2WO4·2H2O/ H3PO4, Na2SO4, and H2SO4 in the aqueous phase. The organic phase consisted of limonene, Adogen® 464 as the phase transfer catalyst (PTC), and a solvent (CHCl3 or EtOAc) to prevent by-product formation and unpredictable temperature increase due to the exothermic reaction. H2SO4 was added to maintain the solution's pH between 0.5 and 1.6, while Na2SO4 was added to saturate the 30 wt% aqueous H2O2 solution and prevent epoxide hydrolysis. Adogen® 464 was used as the PTC. Na2WO4·2H2O/ H3PO4 was not used as the two phases were immiscible. Moreover, the formation of complex compound H 3 [ P O 4 ( W O 4 ) 4 ] as shown in Eq. (1), did not transfer to the organic phase in the absence of the PTC. The complex compound H 3 [ P O 4 ( W O 4 ) 4 ] further interacted with H2O2 to form H 3 { P O 4 [ W ( O ) ( O 2 ) 2 ] 4 } as shown in Eq. (2). (1) H 3 P O 4 + 4 N a 2 W O 4 + H 2 O 2 → H 3 [ P O 4 ( W O 4 ) 4 ] + 8 N a O H (2) H 3 [ P O 4 ( W O 4 ) 4 ] + 4 H 2 O 2 → H 3 { P O 4 [ W ( O ) ( O 2 ) 2 ] 4 } + 4 H 2 O In the presence of the quaternary ammonium salt (QCl), the active oxidizing agent Q 3 { P O 4 [ W ( O ) ( O 2 ) 2 ] 4 } was formed in the aqueous phase. This agent was then transferred into the organic phase, where it reacted with limonene to form both limonene-1,2-epoxide and limonene bis-epoxide, as depicted in Fig. 9. 4 Conclusions This study describes the rapid epoxidation of limonene using environmentally benign H2O2 as an oxidant, resulting in a 96% conversion of limonene with 80% selectivity for limonene-1,2-epoxide and 19% for limonene bis-epoxide. The decomposition of H2O2 was negligible under the investigated operating conditions. Various process variables were studied, such as the limonene: H2O2 molar ratio, reaction time, temperature, and solvent type. The best results were achieved using a 1:1.5 molar ratio of H2O2 and limonene in ethyl acetate with sodium sulphate in 15 min. Changing the inorganic salt increased the selectivity of limonene-1,2-epoxide by preventing the hydrolysis process. Kinetic studies revealed a first-order reaction with respect to limonene and the catalyst. Additionally, a reaction mechanism for limonene epoxidation was proposed. Overall, this study demonstrated that rapid limonene epoxidation can be achieved in almost stoichiometric yields by adding the oxidant in a single step under carefully selected operating conditions. However, there are certain limitations and areas for improvement that can be addressed in future studies. Future studies could focus on developing more efficient catalysts that enhance the reaction rate and selectivity and investigate their recyclability to reduce costs and waste. Moreover, it would be valuable to include a more comprehensive comparison with other existing methods for limonene epoxidation, highlighting the advantages and limitations of the proposed approach. Research on surfactants, phase transfer catalysts, inorganic salts, and reaction kinetics is necessary to guide the future design of innovative catalysts for green epoxidation that are simple to separate and regenerate. Addressing these limitations can contribute to the development of more efficient, sustainable, and scalable methods for utilizing limonene as a valuable bio-renewable feedstock. coredata.dc:description: Terpene epoxides play a vital role as chemical intermediates in industries such as flavourings, fragrances, paints, and polymers manufacturing. However, current methods for limonene epoxidation suffer from low selectivity and environmental concerns. To address these limitations, we aimed to develop a highly selective and environmentally benign process for limonene epoxidation. Our approach involved employing hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) as an oxidant in the presence of tungsten-based polyoxometalates as catalysts. A novel catalyst was synthesized using sodium tungstate dihydrate (Na2WO4·2H2O), phosphoric acid (H3PO4), sulfuric acid (H2SO4), and sodium sulfate (Na2SO4) as an inorganic salt. We investigated the influence of various process variables, including the limonene:H2O2 molar ratio, reaction time, temperature, and solvent type, to optimize the epoxidation process. Through systematic screening, we achieved remarkable results, attaining 96% limonene conversion, 80% selectivity to limonene-1,2-epoxide, and 19% selectivity to limonene bis-epoxide within a short reaction time of 15 min. Notably, this high performance was accomplished by introducing H2O2 in a single step. To mitigate the hydrolysis of the epoxide, we employed sodium sulphate (Na2SO4) to saturate the reaction mixture. Furthermore, we proposed a comprehensive mechanism for the limonene epoxidation process using tungsten-based polyoxometalates as catalysts. Our kinetic study revealed a first-order reaction with respect to both limonene and the catalyst. Importantly, the decomposition of H2O2 was negligible under the investigated operating conditions, confirming the stability and efficiency of our approach. Our findings present eco-friendly, scalable, and catalytic epoxidation methods as valuable synthetic tools for converting inexpensive bio-renewable terpene feedstocks into essential chemical building blocks. The implications of our work extend to the synthesis of useful chemical products in a biorefinery setting, promoting a more sustainable and efficient utilization of terpenes.
coredata.dc:title: Environment-friendly epoxidation of limonene using tungsten-based polyoxometalate catalyst
